newsitem.title: USA: US Treasuries tread lower at midday before supply.
newsitem.headline: US Treasuries tread lower at midday before supply.

text.p: U.S. Treasury prices treaded lower at midday on Wednesday just in front of the Treasury's auction of five-year notes.
The Treasury will sell $12.5 billion in five-year notes in the afternoon. The deadline for bids is 1300 EDT/1700 GMT. Auction results are due around 1340 EDT.

On Tuesday, the Treasury sold $18.25 billion in two-year notes. The auction was well bid but despite that, there was little follow-through buying and the market conceded territory in the trading that followed the sale.
The market opened a touch firmer and then lost a tiny bit of ground in early trade. In late morning activity, prices were moving in the narrowest of trading ranges.
In the hour preceding the bidding deadline for the five-year note auction, the market backed down a bit.
The when-issued yield on the new five-year notes edged up to 6.32 percent.
Late Monday, traders had estimated that the five-year notes would be sold at a yield between 6.30 percent and 6.32 percent.

Five-year Treasury notes last were auctioned on September 26. At that time the notes were sold at a 6.409 percent yield, the bid-to-cover ratio was 2.57, and non-competitive bids totaled $477 million.
Dimick said he saw no reason for this auction to fail and said, "It could give us a little boost if we get another successful auction."
But he said he did not think a good auction could generate a larger move.
"We could move back to overnight highs -- back to about 6.83 percent on the bond yield," he said.
For while Dimick said there was not much to block a market path upward, there was also nothing specific to propel it to higher levels.

"The 110-16 area on the bond contract represents the bottom of the trading channel that you can draw on the September-October rally," said Dimick. "You break the trend if you close below that floor and that would trigger selling rather than buying."
Dimick said that while he is fundamentally constructive on the bond market, technical factors and supply make him a little defensive.
"Supply and the fact that we're challenging the bottom of recent ranges lead me to tread cautiously here," he said.
Elsewhere, McDonough, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, will speak at a small business awards luncheon in New Jersey at 1300 EDT/1700 GMT.
In early afternoon, three-month bill rates were up one basis point to five percent, six-month and year-bill rates were unchanged at 5.14 percent and 5.27 percent, respectively.
The 6-1/2 percent ten-year note was down 3/32 to 99-12/32, yielding 6.59 percent.
After being up 2/32 at the open, the 6-3/4 percent 30-year bond was down 2/32 to 98-19/32, yielding 6.86 percent.
-- North American Treasury Desk, 212-859-1679
